 In order to answer the question over whether states should be allowed to seceed, I must first point out the distinction between individual people and government. I do not disagree that we should protect the freedom and equality of people. Any person or group of people should be allowed to disassociate themselves with the US, to leave the US, change his will etc. Individuals should have as much power and control over their lives as possible. But governments are not people. Governments should have as little control over the people as possible. Governments do not have fundamental liberties; they exist to protect the fundamental liberties of the people as much as possible.
 
 This doesn't mean that governments should not be allowed to form associations that they can later resolve, but it also does not mean that governments should always be allowed the power to disassociate themselves. The Constitution did not create a confederacy; it did not create a set of individual nations bound together by an agreement to listen to a set of federal decision-makers at the top. The Constitution created a single nation, and a single nation has a single government. The power of that government was split up into many branches. There are state level branches, which each state would decide, as well Federal level branches, such as the Executive, Legislative, and Judicial branches. But even though this nation is subdivided into states, the Constitution still created only one nation, one government. The land belongs to the nation, the people are citizens of the nation, and one government rules over the nation (though individuals may be appointed differently and have different powers). 
 
 By accepting the Constitution, the states did not just agree to some alliance or treaty; they agreed to become a nation. And in a nation, no small group of government officials has the right to decree that they no longer recognize the power of a different part of the government. The people governing a state should have no more power to break away from the government than the President has to break away from Congress. Although there may be some situation where Congress is so tyrannical that the President is morally obligated to say, "Congress, your power or authority is no longer recognized, and someone else will have your power", the President certainly has no political right to do this. In the same note, the state-level branch of government should not have the power to say, "Federal branch, this state will no longer recognize your power and authority, and someone else will now have your power". The state government isn't the leaders of the state; they're just people who decide certain laws for that state. The land of the state does not belong to the state officials; it belongs to the nation.
 
 So in accepting the Constitution, the state governments agreed not to be individual nations any longer, but to be sections of a single nation. When people talk about states' rights, they talk about the powers granted to the branches of government that deal specifically with states.

At one time most of all islands were owned by decedents of missionary families. I remember the Bishop Trust still owned a big portion of Oahu in the 1970s, not unlike Manhattan being sold for beads. Only tiny Ni'ihau remains in Hawaiian hands, with residence restricted to a specified percentage of Hawaiian bloodline and by invitation only.
